Award.AwardTitle: Economic Statistics and the Challenge of Democratic Control

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Government economic statistics are Janus-faced. On the one hand, they have an extensive role
in modern governance in which they are treated as apolitical, empirical facts: Statistics are used to guide policy, and to allocate or adjust resources automatically. In these roles, the non-partisan character of official statistics is essential. On the other hand, methodological decisions must be guided by a clear set of measurement goals; yet, every major economic statistic has many such possible goals, and even economists frequently argue about the proper objectives. However, insofar as these statistics are simultaneously used to guide, evaluate, or enact policies, then a decision about measurement goals is defacto a decision about the policy objectives for the relevant programs. These two competing aspects of economic statistics pose a challenge: how can official statistics be subject to democratic oversight and control while retaining their non-partisan character and serving as a bulwark against the abuse of political power? This project aims to explore and resolve this challenge.


This project aims to transform the way Americans construct and understand economic statistics, a goal that requires both theoretical analysis and broader outreach. Funding for the project will support the design of a new undergraduate course on the conceptual foundations of economic statistics that will become the basis for a text book targeted toward undergraduates, policymakers, and journalists. Second, funding will support the construction of a website on price indexes for these audiences that will explain basic conceptual issues, digest recent methodological research, and provide an ongoing, non-partisan commentary about policy issues connected with these statistics. This site will be a pilot program for a future, expanded version that will cover all major macroeconomic statistics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Federal statistics are used to guide policy, to inform democratic debate, and to shape the distribution of federal funds. In these roles, the non-partisan character of official statistics is essential. At the same time, every major federal statistic has many possible measurement goals, and even the experts frequently argue about the proper objectives. In a democracy, we might expect that these choices about measurement goals should be subject to democratic control. But that presents a problem, since defining a measurement goal requires making highly technical methodological decisions. In truth, the measurement goal for a statistic is simply a reflection of its methodology; you only know what GDP means when you have fully explored how the data are gathered and how the results are calculated.

So, if defining the measurement goal for a statistic requires defining a fully-detailed methodology, then how can citizens (who lack the necessary technical expertise) exercise proper democratic oversight? Moreover, if citizens were to control statistical methodology, how could the statistics remain non-partisan? How can we meet legitimate demands for democratic control over statistical knowledge while retaining its non-partisan character and allowing it to serve as a bulwark against the abuse of political power?

This project aims to resolve this dilemma by adopting perspectives drawn from contemporary virtue ethics. I show that well-functioning government statistics inescapably require that citizens trust statistial agencies. I argue that such trust should be built on two foundations: a commitment by agencies to fostering reasoned, democratic deliberation and a conviction that agency staff members have the proper character (inculding cognitive, emotional, and behavioral traits) to carry out that goal. Statisticians must be just, courageous, and truthful -- but they also must be open-minded, creative, perceptive, display intellectual humility, and be able to understand the perspectives of others with very different backgrounds and experience. Above all, they must be dedicated to building a vibrant civic life based on reasoned debate and democratic politics. In short, they must be virtuous statisticians.

Understanding these objectives allows us to consider how we might cultivate and support these virtues. What kind of training can provide fertile ground for virtuous traits? What institutional practices can support them? How can a proper community be built and sustained to allow such virtues to flourish? 

I am exploring these questions through a book, The Virtuous Statistician: How to Help Government Statistics Serve Democratic Life, multiple chapters of which were completed during this grant. I have been able to present preliminary work at multiple venues, as well as publish two supporting articles.

Beyond the book, the grant has allowed me to develop materials for an undergraduate course that will examine the political economy of macroeconomic statistics, and thereby help young economists think about how government statistics shape, and are shaped by, our political life. The grant has also supported the development of a pilot website that examines the conceptual debates behind the U.S. Consumer Price Index and helps non-economists understand the policy ramifications of various methodological choices.
